model.dek: Cond√© Nast Traveler readers rate the top hotels in Chicago, Illinois

memberComments.comment: "Wonderful little hotel. The fireplaces in the lobby were so welcome on a cold day. The staff was excellent."
"Fantastic service, rooms are great, and the restaurant is one of the hottest in town."
"The hand-crafted cocktails and fantastic small bites coupled with an overwhelming majority of handsome strangers make Sable, the Palomar's restaurant, one of my favorites in the city."
Super nice rooms , right off of the Magnificent Mile. The adjacent mall is top notch and very convenient.
Quiet and calm oasis from the city. The rooftop bar is a great place to enjoy drinks and food while sitting on sofas and enjoying the skyline of Chicago.
The choice of restaurants is overwhelming.
A wonderful hotel very close to Downtown. Wonderful views of the lake. Walking distance to a variety of shops and Millennium Park. Would definitely stay here again!
A beautiful facility with a wonderful view from our room.  Well trained staff; the food was good, but not outstanding.
Upscale and elegant. Coffee on the executive floor overlooking Lake Michigan is a treat in the morning.
Warm chocolate-chip cookies on arrival were a really nice touch!
Fun, young, modern vibe  in the city's theater district.

items.name: Waldorf Astoria Chicago
items.description: "From the decor to the service, this is one of the greatest hotels I‚Äôve stayed in." This "oasis of luxury" (opened at the end of 2009 as The Elysian) is in the Gold Coast neighborhood, steps from the lakefront. Designed to emulate the grand hotels of Paris in the 1920s, it is set in a 60-story tower that has colonnades, spires, and a motor court. The "fantastic, spacious rooms," ten per floor, have fireplaces, furnished terraces, Italian linens, and white Carrara marble bathrooms with soaking tubs. "Staff make you feel welcome, like they‚Äôre really excited that you chose their hotel." "Epicurean paradises" include the European-style bistro Balsan, which focuses on sustainable local ingredients. "I‚Äôd like to move in‚Äînow."

fields.title: [United States](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/united-states)
fields.caption: The top-scoring Gold List property in the United States, the [Elysian Chicago](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/elysian-chicago-chicago-illinois) emulates the grand hotels of Paris in the 1920s, set in a 60-story tower that has colonnades, spires, and a motor court. Overall score: 98.2

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Chicago
items.description: "All you expect from a Four Seasons," this hotel in a 66-story Burgundy limestone building is "great for business and leisure travelers," thanks to its proximity to the offices and shops on the Magnificent Mile. Professional staff are "driven to exceed expectations." The decor is contemporary, with a palette of blues, taupes, browns, and silvers, but the modern furniture is "a little impersonal." Rooms have large windows (some with leather window benches) offering views of Lake Michigan and the skyline. Try the aromatic herbal mud wrap at the spa, which is paneled in imitation suede.

items.name: Park Hyatt Chicago
items.description: "Right on the Magnificent Mile, this hotel represents elegance at its best, and yet the staff are not at all pretentious." "The location, service, and way they treat guests cannot be beat." Filling about a third of the 67-story limestone Park Tower, the hotel opened in 2001 in "an excellent location for shopping and sightseeing." Rooms have sleek decor with cherrywood, black granite, leather Eames chairs, glass desks, and sunken tubs; they have views of Lake Michigan or the historic Water Tower Place. The NoMI Kitchen, with Dale Chihuly glass sculptures in the private dining rooms, serves casual cuisine with a focus on local ingredients, hence dishes like prime beef rib eye with red onion jam.

fields.title: Park Hyatt, Chicago
fields.caption:
**Overall Score: 93.4**


See full rating information** **for** [Park Hyatt, Chicago](/hotels/north-america/united-states/park-hyatt-chicago-chicago-illinois)


 **

items.name: Renaissance Blackstone Chicago Hotel
items.description: Dubbed "the hotel of presidents," this South Loop mainstay on Grant Park has hosted more than a dozen leaders of the United States, including Roosevelt, Truman, and Kennedy when he was informed of the Cuban Missile Crisis. (It even had a special room for the Secret Service, separated from the rest of the hotel by hollowed-out walls.) Modern-day renovations have "preserved its historic charm." The Heavens Suite, on the 23rd floor, has 17-foot vaulted ceilings, skylights, and contemporary design. At the open air market‚Äìstyle Mercat a la Planxa, dine on Spanish tapas, meat, and seafood dishes by Iron Chef Jose Garces.

items.name: Ritz-Carlton, Chicago
items.description: Right on the Magnificent Mile, on floors 15 through 30 of the marble-and-glass Water Tower Place, this hotel is "right in the center of the action." The lobby, with 19-foot ceilings and a skylit fountain, has "a fabulous ambience," though some complain it‚Äôs "old-looking and stuffy." "Updates made to the rooms in 2009 are very nice‚Äîthe rooms are peaceful and calming." Accommodations in pewter or blue topaz color schemes blend contemporary and traditional furnishings. The Presidential Suite even has a baby grand piano in the living area. The food at Deca is "consistently terrific," while "staff are always wonderful and welcoming." Undergoing a major renovation for two years, beginning in late 2015, the hotel remains open (although no longer with any affiliation to the Four Seasons group).

items.name: The James
items.description: Two blocks from Michigan Avenue, this slick 297-room hotel, formerly the Lenox Suites, mixes mod cons with tongue-in-cheek fun. The minimalist interior showcases dark-wood furniture, slate-and-marble bathrooms, and eye-catching Gen Art installations by Chicago artists. The property‚Äôs cool factor sometimes comes at the expense of practicality, though: Standard rooms don‚Äôt have full-length mirrors, and the only closet space is located, inexplicably, inside the bathroom. But an attentive staff, a 24-hour concierge desk, and twice daily maid service more than compensate. Its restaurant David Burke‚Äôs Primehouse has an on-site salt cave for dry-aging.

items.name: The Peninsula Chicago
items.description: "The Asian calm of the decor cannot be beat" at this concrete tower that occupies an entire city block of the Magnificent Mile. Notable for its stained-glass wall, the lobby has a gilded ceiling, 20-foot floor-to-ceiling windows, marble floors, and, on weekends, a chocolate bar. The "spectacular top-floor, glass-enclosed pool" comes with skyline views. The hotel recently unveiled its latest iteration of opulence with a major room renovation that features a mod white interior design and a sweeping tablet-driven technology system. One floor of rooms is nearly complete with the rest slated to be finished by April 2016. Which is when this Chicago classic will become the city‚Äôs‚Äîand the brand‚Äôs‚Äîmost high-tech hotel. The "excellent restaurants" include Shanghai Terrace, which serves Shanghainese and Cantonese in an ambience reminiscent of a 1930s supper club. "This is the gold standard for service at any hotel in America."

items.name: theWit
items.description: This smart downtown hotel on reviving State Street combines business traveler essentials with a buzzy scene and quirky touches like recorded birdsong in the hallways. At check-in, stylish front desk staff dispense warm chocolate chip cookies along with insider advice on the nightlife‚Äîalthough you may feel like staying put, since the two-story glass lobby broadcasts music 24/7 while, on warm evenings, fashionable young things line up awaiting access to the hotel‚Äôs large rooftop bar. Double-layered glass muffles the noise of elevated commuter trains rumbling directly past architect Jackie Koo‚Äôs jazzy 27-story tower. In the 298 cheerful teal- and magenta-accented rooms, deep soaking tubs face floor-to-ceiling windows; aerie suites on the top floors have kitchens and chaise longues from which to admire views of the famed skyline, the Chicago River, and Lake Michigan. The Wit lives up to its name: Some of the more artful touches include the lobby‚Äôs anim√©-inspired mural of a woman morphing into a phoenix rising (a reference to the Great Chicago Fire); wake-up calls recorded by actors from the Second City improv troupe posing as "The Prez," Muddy Waters, and other Chicago celebs; framed epigrams as wall art; and Rubik‚Äôs cubes as turndown gifts.

items.name: Trump International Hotel & Tower Chicago
items.description:
Stack 339 ‚Äúsensational rooms‚Äù and suites into a 92-storey-tall tower, lording over the Loop and North Michigan Avenue, and you have a ‚Äúfirst class,‚Äù if ‚Äúsomewhat pricey,‚Äù stunner of a hotel.

The Trump Hotel in Chicago provides a perfect view of the Navy Pier show from its 16th-floor restaurant The Terrace at Trump. While a few tables can be booked for $100 a head‚Äînot including food and drink‚Äîthere‚Äôs also plenty of space for walk-ins who arrive early enough to beat the crowd.

Bonus: Unfurl a yoga mat on the hotel's 16th-story riverfront terrace and do a series of meditative poses with the talented yoga instructor, Kristin Krupa. But this isn't the time to shut your eyes and reflect: Look to the east and catch the sun‚Äôs early morning rays reflecting off Lake Michigan, or south to drink in the gorgeous Chicago skyline. (6 a.m. Wednesdays; 401 North Wabash Ave; 312-588-8126).
